text:
JENNIFER JORDAN: So we're
talking about power.

We're talking about
two types of power.

First of all, there's
personalized power,

which is how powerful
you feel in your life.

You can make
choices for yourself

without asking
permission from others.

And then there is
social power, which

is how much power
you have over people

or how much power you have over
things that other people want.

We need personal power
to feel good in life.

And in an
organizational context,

it's really social power
that is most relevant.
How do we get that social power?

Often by seizing
control over things

that other people
value in that system.

And I don't only
mean tangible things.

It can also mean
people's attention,
it can mean reputation.

So socialized power is really
that power over others.

Many people are uncomfortable
talking about power.

My philosophy as a
scholar is, no taboos.

Everything in my
classroom is fair game

to talk about because I think
dialogue is so important.

However, there is a
negative connotation

or a negative taste
that sometimes
comes with that word, power.

And I think that is
because of the way

the media highlights
those with power.

They tend to highlight
those who abuse power.

But if we think
about the people that

have made really benevolent
differences in this world,
they have had incredible power.

And I don't mean control
over material resources only.

Reputation is also
a source of power.

What are other people
saying about you?

Followers-- the more
followers you have.
For example, Nelson Mandela--
very low personal power.

As a prisoner for
over two decades,
you would say almost none.

But incredible social power
through the followership

that he was able to garner
through the vision that he had.

In a workplace context,
leaders are always

trying to figure out, how
do I get more social power?

How do I get more power over
the environment or the groups
around me, even a team?

Do we hope that those leaders
are using it for benevolence?
Yes, we do.

To get power, you need bases
of power that you harness.

And there are three
categories of bases of power.
The first ones are innate.

And when we talk about
the taboos of power,

these are the ones that are
really taboo, that people
don't like to talk about.

I think it's important
to acknowledge them.

Gender can be a base of power
in certain environments.

There are environments
where it helps

to be a man-- that just by being
a man, you have more power.

And there's actually
environments
where it helps to be a woman.

Physical attractiveness can
be an innate base of power.

For men, at least,
height can be a base.

These are things that we're
born with that we cannot change.

And we need to acknowledge
that they are bases of power,
including in the workplace.

Then comes what I call
primary bases of power.

These are things
that you can work

to earn which help to elevate
your power in the system.
They can be education--

certain degrees, trainings
you can go through.

Tacit knowledge-- how much
do you know that system
that you're working in?

Your allies-- who
is supporting you?

Your reputation-- what are
people saying about you?

Your network
centrality-- are people

having to go through
you to get things

or to get to people
that they want?

And then there are
secondary bases of power

that come from these
primary bases of power.
That is place in the hierarchy.

Having more allies helps
lift you up in the hierarchy.

Having a better
reputation can help

you to be a more central
player in the network.

So network centrality
is both a primary--
it can be also a secondary.

Bases of power are
mutually reinforcing.

If I have more allies
in that system,

I'm also probably going to
move up in that hierarchy.

Or people are
saying more things,
positive things about me--

it also might help me to
become a more central player.

Now if you want to get
more power in your system,
I recommend doing a power audit.

First of all, say,
what are the bases

of power that are most
valued in this system?

Listen for the
people around you.
Who is listening to whom?

Who are the movers and
shakers in this environment?
So listen and watch.

What is it that
these people have?
What is unique about them?

Is it that they're
very articulate?

Is it that they've been at
this company a long time?

Is it that they have
a lot of contacts

internally, maybe a lot
of contacts externally?

Is it that they have credentials
from their previous roles?

And then look at
yourself and rate--

in a way that is as
objective as possible-- how

much of these power
bases do you have.

How good are your allies
in this organization?

How much of a central player
are you in the network?

And to say, OK, what are
those secondary bases that

are valued in that company,
that maybe I don't possess
but that I could develop?

And start to come up with
a plan of developing those.

It takes about six months
of observing the environment
to be able to do this.

So you can't do it on your
first day in the company,

but you can do it
after about six months.

For young managers,
the two bases

of power that are
the low hanging fruit
are expertise and allies.

And what I mean by that is
that, if you have an expertise--

you're an amazing
Python programmer.
Or now it's with AI, right?

You have some background
in machine learning.
You come in.

You can be the youngest
one in the room,
and people listen to you.

They want to hear
what you have to say,

and they will be
influenced by you.
The other one is allies.

Even if you're very
young and junior,

having one or two of the movers
and shakers in that environment

that are backing you
up-- that are saying,
I vouch for this person.

I've seen them, I
trust their abilities,
I trust their intention.

That can be an incredible
route to getting power

fairly quickly at a young age
or a young stage in your career.

For leaders that are
a bit more developed,

the two power bases that
I've seen being, in general,

most critical to
gain are reputation--

what are people saying about
you-- and network centrality.

This is a really important
one to understand about power.

Power is completely
dependent on the context.

So, for example, being able to
run a kilometer very quickly

gives you a lot of
power on a track team,

but it's not going to matter
so much in the boardroom.
Power is context dependent.

I also experienced
this shift firsthand.

I used to be in a
very traditional

academic institution--
a public university.

And there, there were
two bases of power--
expertise.

Were you the number
one expert in a field?

Did you publish 20
papers, and did your peers
cite you as the expert?

And resources--
were you bringing
in big government grants?

In this new environment at
IMD, I took my six months.

I did my power audit
and I realized,

expertise is important,
but not the most important.

And resources-- we
don't apply for grants,

so I could put that
power base to the side.

In this new environment, I
needed to develop two things--
one, reputation.

Caring about what my colleagues
and what my clients were saying

about me-- because that made
all the difference for getting

new clients and getting
on new programs.

And network centrality--
were you a central player

in the network and
did people need

to go through you to get to
important contexts in companies

and to get things
done institutionally?

So I had to say,
OK, drop my ego.

Let my ego go and
say those two power

bases that I worked so
hard previously to develop
are no longer so valuable.
How do I develop the new ones?

I talked a lot about having
power, but having power,

gaining power, isn't
the ultimate goal.

The ultimate goal is
to show leadership,

which includes
influence-- to have
influence on that environment.

You can have a legitimate
base of power--

let's say hierarchical
position--

but not have what is called
status, which is other people's
recognition of that power.

So maybe you've
worked for a boss

or had a boss or an
individual in a company that

has a lot of
hierarchical position,
but no one listens to them.
They're not influential.

As a power holder, once
you gain that power,
you want to gain the status--
people's recognition of it.

And that has to do a lot with
how are you using your power?

Are you using your power
to bring the organization
or the team up?

And are you using
power to help others?

I worked, for example,
in a medical institution.

And there was one person who
was really a power wielder--
used their power very selfishly.

But they were the only expert
in this one area of medicine.

So people needed
to rely on them,
but they weren't respected.

For this individual-- let's
call him Dr. X. For Dr. X,
his expertise was very valued.

But playing the competency
game is dangerous.

Because if someone
else were to come

in that system with equal
competency, people, I guarantee,

would have been happy
to see Dr. X go.

Using power for
benevolence, and also

showing self control--
not abusing that power

and abusing the people
through having that power.

There's an ethical
standpoint, but it also

helps you to get that
status and it will help
stabilize our power in return.
Power is not good nor evil.

Do you want to use it
for benevolence or mere
self-aggrandizement?

And thinking about also, not
only how much power do you have,

but how do you get
others to recognize it?

And that recognition,
that status,

is also often about
how you use the power.

Are you using it for yourself
or using it for others?
